content.text: **Syllogisms** are arguments using syllogistic wffs where each letter occurs twice and the letters 'form a chain.' The last wff is the conclusion; other wffs are premises.

content.title: A Valid Syllogism
premises: No pure water is burnable. → no P is B
Some Cuyahoga River water is burnable. → some C is B
content.conclusion: ∴ Some Cuyahoga River water isn't pure water. → some C is not P
content.note: Notice how letters form a chain: P-B, C-B, C-P. Each letter appears exactly twice.

content.definition: A letter is distributed in a wff if it occurs just after 'all' or anywhere after 'no' or 'not.' Distributed terms cover their entire category.

symbols.name: A distributed
symbols.example: A* is distributed, B is not

content.text: The **star test** is a quick method to check if a syllogism is valid. It takes about 5 seconds once you've mastered it!

content.definition: Star premise letters that ARE distributed and conclusion letters that are NOT distributed. Valid if: (1) every capital letter is starred exactly once, and (2) there is exactly one star on the right-hand side (after 'is' or 'is not').

content.title: Star Test Example - VALID
premises: all A* is B (A is distributed, so star it)
some C is A (nothing distributed in premises)
content.conclusion: ∴ some C* is B* (C and B not distributed, so star them)
content.note: Each capital starred once ✓ One right-hand star (B*) ✓ = VALID

content.title: Star Test Example - INVALID
premises: no A* is B* (both distributed after 'no')
no C* is A* (both distributed after 'no')
content.conclusion: ∴ no C is B (both distributed - don't star!)
content.note: A starred twice ✗ Two right-hand stars ✗ = INVALID

content.question: In 'all A is B', which letter is distributed?
content.explanation: Only the first letter after 'all' is distributed. In 'all A is B', A is distributed (covers all of category A) but B is not (we only know some B's are A's).
